subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] What to call the Read Quikscript Alphabet
msgSnippet: Benct: I am not sure whether you are dismissing The Read Newsletter to avoid confusion with your hypothetical university or whether you think we could be
messageBody:
Benct:

I am not sure whether you are dismissing "The Read Newsletter" to avoid
confusion with your hypothetical university or whether you think we
could be prohibited from using it if there is a university using that
name. Unless it is a trademark, which I would seriously doubt, I don't
think we could be forced to desist from using it if we decided to.

According to Google: READ Global is a group promoting literacy in
Nepal. There webpage mentions the READ Newsletter.

We could call it "Quikscript News," and it could include news about QS
as well as news in QS.

Or we could call it "Read's Quikscript Alphabet News" although that
might be getting a little unwieldy.

Paige

Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:

>
> There surely is some university or company out there called
> Read, so "The Read Newsletter" is probably out.
>
> There are several computer applications, notably a
> PostScript based DTP program called Qui(c)kscript with
> different capitalizations. I don't think we should need to
> care, since Read's Quikscript was there before all of those,
> but the fact remains.
>
> Of course googling for "read alphabet" of course gives
> zillions of unrelated hits (""read alphabet"" -- i.e. with
> the words actually double-quoted in the search string -- at
> least returns some relevant hits on the first page), so I
> don't think "The Read Alphabet" is a good designation
> either. (Incidentally it hand't been any better if the man
> had spelled his name Reed, as people might then have
> believed you's have to use a reed pen to write it! :-)
>
> I for one always think of the Read Alphabet as Quikscript,
> so I actually suggest
>
> "The Read Quikscript Alphabet"
>
> as a compromise designation, which can't very well refer to
> something else. The word "Alphabet" should probably be
> icluded, since my experience as a classroom shorthand user
> is that the uninitiated for some reason tend to believe that
> writing consisting in squiggly lines probably isn't
> alphabetic, and that there hence are zillions of distinct
> signs to learn, so the point that Read Quikscript is an
> alphabet should probably be hammered home.
>
> Just my two pieces of small change. Maybe I should quit
> Academia and go into trademark profiling or whatever it's
> called! :-)
>
> --
>
> /BP 8^)
> --
> B.Philip Jonsson mailto:melrochX@...
> <mailto:melrochX%40melroch.se> (delete X)
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
> "Truth, Sir, is a cow which will give [skeptics] no more milk,
> and so they are gone to milk the bull."
> -- Sam. Johnson (no rel. ;)
>
>

I am not sure whether you are dismissing "The Read Newsletter" to avoid 
confusion with your hypothetical university or whether you think we 
could be prohibited from using it if there is a university using that

According to Google:  READ Global is a group promoting literacy in

Or we could call it "Read's Quikscript Alphabet News" although that 
might be getting a little unwieldy.
